physical_appearance: This print depicts a portrait of Commodore Sir Nathaniel Dance. It is engraved as mezzotint. He is posing in a building and his right hand is resting on a open scroll which is atop a table. He is dressed in the attire of a British naval officer. Below the image, its title is displayed in capital letters. Under its title, there are three rows of lines indicating that this artwork had been dedicated to The Earl Camden.  This is a portrait of a man. He wears a coat, stands with his right calm on the table adjacent to him, and looks directly at the viewer. A stack of books, telescope, and maps are sprawled across the table, and above the table to the left of the print is framed painting of ships at sea.
sgcool_label_text: Commodore Sir Nathaniel Dance was the captain of a fleet of British East Indiamen which had defeated a French squadron off the Straits of Malacca on 15 February 1804. This portrait was painted and engraved as a mezzotint by English artist, engraver and publisherJohn Raphael Smith (1752-1812), engraver to the Prince of Wales. Smith  was renown for his mastery of  mezzotint printing.
